title: ISIS bride Shamima Begum fears she will be assassinated by 'psychotic women'
text:

ISIS bride Shamima Begum fears former jihadist friends will kill her in revenge for quitting their cause.

The former east London schoolgirl fled Britain with two other schoolmates and is currently staying in the al-Roj camp, nine miles from the Turkish border in Syria.

She claimed that she is ready to flee at any moment - and told The Times in an interview: "It's like the earlier days in the time of ISIS."

She and her fellow campmates have got bags ready and waiting to move quickly if the situation changes, she added.

The 20-year-old also said: "I am scared, really scared. I am afraid I could die here.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

"The camp is very tense. When the Turkish offensive began many of the women here waited to take advantage of it to hurt those who had left ISIS.

"There are some psychotic women in here."

Her fears come after Russia and Turkey agreed that the Kurdish forces must withdraw from within 30km of the border including the al-Roj camp.

Begum is currently appealing the withdrawal of her British citizenship by the Government but has little hope of success.

Tom Hickman QC told Mrs Justice Elisabeth Laing that the situation in the al-Roj camp where his client is currently held is “incredibly fragile and dangerous”.

(Image: BBC)

In written submissions, he described conditions, where Ms Begum’s third child died in March, as “wretched and squalid”, adding that “the tragic death of the appellant’s infant child ... demonstrates that fact”.

The court is being asked to determine “whether the deprivation decision rendered the applicant stateless”.

The Home Office says the decision does not.

Mr Hickman said the court also had to decide “whether the deprivation decision gave rise to a real risk of death or degrading and inhuman treatment”.

In his written case, the Home Office’s barrister, Jonathan Glasson QC, argued that Ms Begum “was a Bangladeshi citizen by descent, in accordance with Bangladeshi law, and so was not rendered stateless by the deprivation decision”.

Begum was one of three schoolgirls from Bethnal Green Academy who left their homes and families to join IS.

Kadiza Sultana and Amira Abase, then 16 and 15 respectively, and Ms Begum boarded a flight from Gatwick Airport to Istanbul, Turkey, on February 17, 2015, before making their way to Raqqa in Syria.
description: The 20-year-old said there were some 'psychotic women' in her refugee camp in  Syria where she awaits the result of an appeal over her British citizenship loss
